waterNeeds: Drought-tolerant once established. Prefers well-drained soil and infrequent, deep watering.
flowerInfo: Small, fragrant white, pink, purple, or blue flowers (often pale violet-blue and white), borne in leaf axils. Blooms in spring/summer, can flower continuously in warmer regions.
notes: Aromatic evergreen shrub. Drought-tolerant. Attracts pollinators. Native to the Mediterranean.

waterNeeds: Drought-tolerant once established. Prefers well-drained soil and infrequent watering.
flowerInfo: Dusky blue-violet (cultivars include purple, pink, white) flowers on spikes up to 8 inches long. Blooms late spring to midsummer. Highly aromatic, attracts pollinators.
notes: Popular aromatic shrub. Native to Mediterranean. Attracts pollinators.

waterNeeds: Drought-tolerant once established. Low to moderate water, with occasional deep watering during prolonged dry spells.
flowerInfo: White flowers emerging from prominent, arching, velvety blue or purple (bicolor) calyces on spikes up to 10 inches long. Blooms from late summer until frost (or late spring through winter in warmer areas). Attracts hummingbirds and butterflies.
notes: Evergreen in mild climates, often grown as an annual in colder areas. Attracts hummingbirds, butterflies, and bees.

waterNeeds: Medium water needs. Drought-tolerant once established. Young trees require regular watering.
flowerInfo: Monoecious (both male and female flowers on same tree). Male flowers are catkins, becoming long and pendulous. Female flowers are inconspicuous, very small, lacking petals, emerging from leaf axils. Blooms late spring.
fruitInfo: Brown acorn (0.5-1.5 inches long), matures in second year.
notes: Deciduous. Leaves turn yellow to orange in fall. Important food source for Native Americans.

size: 8-15 feet tall and wide (up to 29 feet tall), 5-10 feet wide (dwarf varieties)
waterNeeds: Drought-tolerant once established. Prefers evenly moist, well-rained soil and deep, infrequent watering.
flowerInfo: Small, urn-shaped or bell-shaped flowers, typically whitish-pink or white (can appear yellow), 7-8 mm in diameter, borne in drooping panicles. Mildly sweet scented, pollinated by bees. Blooms in autumn (Oct-Dec/Jan), coinciding with ripening fruit.
fruitInfo: Red, berry-like pomes (edible, but sour) ripen over a year.
notes: Evergreen. Red to cinnamon-colored flaking bark. Tolerates various soils. Deer resistant.

waterNeeds: Low to very low. Highly drought-tolerant once established. Young trees require moderate watering.
flowerInfo: Monoecious. Male flowers are slender, drooping, yellow-green catkins. Female flowers are small, inconspicuous, greenish-yellow, emerging from leaf axils. Flowers in May (late March to mid-May). Wind-pollinated.
fruitInfo: Acorn (5-10 mm long by 10-15 mm wide), ripens in October.
notes: Deciduous. Bluish-green waxy leaves. Native and endemic to California.

lightRequirements: Full sun (coastal) to full sun/partial shade (inland)
waterNeeds: Drought-tolerant once established. Requires regular watering during its first 1-2 years. Once established, water 1-2 times per week or every 3-4 weeks depending on conditions. Avoid waterlogged soils.
flowerInfo: Small, urn-shaped, white to pink flowers in clusters. Blooms late winter through spring. Attracts moths, hummingbirds, and butterflies.
fruitInfo: Small, brick red or maroon berries (edible).
notes: Evergreen. Dependable and adaptable. Smooth dark red bark. Attracts hummingbirds and butterflies.

waterNeeds: Drought-tolerant. Prefers dry to medium moisture levels and well-drained soil. Water sparingly.
flowerInfo: Inconspicuous, yellow-tinged silver flowers, rarely blooming, typically appearing in late summer. Primarily grown for its aromatic, silver-gray foliage.
notes: Aromatic, silvery-gray foliage. Deer and rabbit resistant. Hybrid cultivar.

size: 30-75 feet tall and wide (can be smaller as shrub)
waterNeeds: Low to moderate water needs. Drought-tolerant once established. Young plants require regular watering.
flowerInfo: Small, yellow or yellowish-green, perfect flowers (contain both male and female parts) borne in small clusters (umbels) of 6-10 flowers. Typically appear in late spring.
fruitInfo: Rounded to elliptical drupes (green to purple, olive-like).
notes: Native to California. Aromatic leaves used as spice, but stronger than true bay leaf. Wood highly valued.

waterNeeds: Prefers moist, well-rained soil. Requires ample water during the growing season, but watering should be reduced during the dormant winter period.
flowerInfo: Showy, fragrant flowers (7-8cm across) with white petals/sepals and prominent blue/purple filaments. Features 5 golden anthers and 3 brown stigmas. Blooms early summer to mid-autumn. Attracts various pollinators.
fruitInfo: Egg-shaped orange fruits (edible, but not desirable flavor).
notes: Vigorous twining climber. Attracts butterflies. Other parts of plant can be toxic.

waterNeeds: Regular watering, especially during hot and dry periods. Prefers evenly moist, well-rained soil. Drought-tolerant once established.
flowerInfo: Clusters of richly fragrant, small white (or pale yellow) star/windmill-shaped flowers with five petals. Blooms throughout summer, sometimes continuously into autumn. Set against glossy green leaves. Attracts bees.
notes: Vigorous evergreen climber. Deer resistant. Not a true jasmine.

waterNeeds: Regular watering during the first growing season. Once established, it is drought-tolerant and requires only occasional deep watering.
flowerInfo: Clusters of fragrant, cream-white or white flowers. Blooms mid-spring to early summer. Attracts bees.
notes: Invasive in some regions. Dense foliage, good for hedges. Deer-resistant.

waterNeeds: Drought-tolerant once established. Prefers well-rained soil and regular watering when young.
flowerInfo: Honey-scented, typically lilac to purple (white varieties exist) flowers in terminal panicles up to 12 inches long. Individual flowers are small with an orange throat. Blooms in summer. Highly attractive to butterflies, hummingbirds, and bees.
notes: Attracts butterflies, bees, and hummingbirds. Can be invasive in some regions.

waterNeeds: Drought-tolerant once established. Requires regular watering during the first growing season and in dry weather.
flowerInfo: Small, pale yellow (sometimes red-tinged), discreet flowers appearing in mid-spring. Primarily grown for its variegated foliage.
notes: Varied foliage color (rose-pink mottled with red/purple, turning burgundy/orange-red in fall). Thorny. Deer-resistant. Invasive potential.

waterNeeds: Drought-tolerant once established. Requires regular watering when newly planted or during dry spells.
flowerInfo: Showy, waxy, trumpet-shaped flowers (up to 3.5 inches long) in clusters of 2-8. Color ranges from orange to scarlet or red, often with a yellowish throat. Blooms throughout summer into fall. No floral scent. Attracts hummingbirds.
fruitInfo: Brown pod (5-7 inches long) with winged seeds.
notes: Vigorous climber. Attracts hummingbirds. Sap can cause skin irritation.

waterNeeds: Prefers consistently moist, well-rained soil. Can tolerate some drought once established.
flowerInfo: Does not produce flowers. As a fern, it reproduces through spores, not seeds or flowers.
notes: Largest American fern. Evergreen fronds. Distinctive chain-like sori on fronds. Prefers rich, loamy, acidic soil.

waterNeeds: Prefers consistently moist, well-rained soil. Regular watering is crucial, especially during dry summer months. Drought-tolerant once established.
flowerInfo: Does not produce flowers. As a fern, it reproduces by spores, found in clusters (sori) on the underside of fronds.
notes: Evergreen or semi-evergreen. Mounding, arching habit. Native to western North America.

waterNeeds: Drought-tolerant once established. Requires deep watering once per month during summer. Young trees need more frequent watering.
flowerInfo: Small, fragrant white or yellowish-white, tubular flowers, borne in panicles (branched clusters) up to 2 inches long. Appear in summer or spring from leaf axils on previous year's wood. Perfect (hermaphrodite) and staminate flowers present. Primarily wind-pollinated.
fruitInfo: Oblong, fleshy, oil-bearing drupe (olive), green to black (edible).
notes: Evergreen. Heat and drought tolerant. Produces allergenic pollen.

waterNeeds: Moderate water needs. Drought-tolerant once established. Regular watering is required for newly planted Nandinas.
flowerInfo: Small, white flowers in frothy clusters on long panicles. Appear in spring or July-August. Flowers can appear pink in bud. Yellow anthers. Attracts bees.
notes: Evergreen/semi-evergreen. Toxic if ingested. Can be invasive. Deer-resistant.

waterNeeds: Drought-tolerant. Requires minimal water once established. Water sparingly, especially in dry summer climates.
flowerInfo: Purple, light amethyst, or rose-purple, thistle-like flowers. Appear at branch tips. Blooms from spring through mid-summer (or May to late summer). Some descriptions mention tiny pink flowers.
notes: Silvery-gray foliage. Deer resistant. Native to Capraia Island (Italy), but often cultivated form is a hybrid.

waterNeeds: Drought-tolerant. Requires deep, infrequent watering. Young trees need more frequent watering for the first two years.
flowerInfo: Small, apetalous (lacking petals) flowers in catkin-like racemes (3.5-15 cm long) bearing 20-60 densely packed flowers. Emerge from twigs/trunk in autumn. Dioecious (male and female on separate trees), though perfect flowers can occur. Staminate (male) flowers are reddish-yellow and have an unpleasant odor. Wind and insect pollinated.
notes: Evergreen. Drought-tolerant. Edible pods used as chocolate substitute.

size: 8-15 feet high, 8 feet wide (up to 30 feet tall)
waterNeeds: Low to very low water needs. Drought-tolerant once established. Occasional deep watering may be beneficial during prolonged dry periods.
flowerInfo: Small, white, fragrant flowers (6-10mm diameter) with five petals, appearing in dense, branched, terminal clusters (corymbs or panicles). Blooms late spring to early summer, peaking in June. Attracts butterflies and other pollinators.
fruitInfo: Abundant clusters of bright red, berry-like pomes (edible after processing).
notes: Evergreen. Native to California. Important winter food source for birds.

waterNeeds: Moderate water. Requires regular watering, especially when newly planted and during dry periods. Drought-tolerant once established.
flowerInfo: Slightly fragrant, bell-shaped, pink-tinged white or pink flowers (approx. 3/4 inch long) with a persistent, reddish calyx. Appear in clusters continuously from late spring/early summer to fall. Attracts butterflies, hummingbirds, and bees.
notes: Evergreen/semi-evergreen. Attracts butterflies, hummingbirds, and bees. Deer and salt resistant. Hybrid.

waterNeeds: Medium water needs. Prefers consistently moist, well-rained soil. Can tolerate some drought once established.
flowerInfo: Sweetly fragrant, bell-shaped, deep pink to red (hybrid varieties can be pink, white, or coral red) flowers, borne in open, airy panicles on slender, leafless stems. Blooms late spring to early summer (May-Jul), extending to early fall with deadheading. Attracts bees and hummingbirds.
notes: Evergreen. Attracts hummingbirds. Native to North America.

waterNeeds: Prefers consistently moist soil. Requires deep watering 1-2 times per week during the growing season. Can tolerate boggy conditions.
flowerInfo: Massive, showy, asymmetrical flowers in shades of pale pastels, vibrant oranges, reds, yellow, pink, scarlet, and creamy white, with some bi- or multi-colored. Appear in clusters at the top of tall stems. Individual flowers are short-lived, but new blooms continuously emerge from early to midsummer until frost.
notes: Tropical appearance. Not a true lily. Rhizomatous. Some species edible.

waterNeeds: Low to moderate water needs. Drought-tolerant once established. Requires deep and regular watering during its initial growing season.
flowerInfo: Small, urn-shaped or bell-shaped, white flowers. Appear in clusters from mid-winter through spring (sometimes as early as Jan/Feb). Attracts bees, butterflies, and hummingbirds.
notes: Groundcover. Glossy green leaves. Cinnamon-red stems. Native to California.

waterNeeds: Drought-tolerant once established. Requires regular watering when young. Prefers well-rained soil and should not be overwatered.
flowerInfo: Fragrant, blue to violet-blue or intense purple flowers. Appear from late summer into fall (August to October). Attracts bees, butterflies, and hummingbirds.
notes: Deciduous. Attracts butterflies, bees, hummingbirds. Deer and rabbit resistant. Hybrid.

waterNeeds: Moderate water needs. Prefers evenly moist, well-rained soil. Drought-tolerant once established.
flowerInfo: Distinctive cobalt blue or deep blue, 5-petaled, star-shaped flowers (1/2 to 3/4 inch diameter). Blooms from late summer to frost, or mid-summer to early fall. Attractive to pollinators.
notes: Mat-forming perennial. Spreads by rhizomes. Striking reddish-bronze fall foliage. Deer-resistant. Native to China.

waterNeeds: Moderate water needs. Drought-tolerant once established, but requires deep weekly watering during flowering and fruit formation for optimal yield.
flowerInfo: Showy, pink and white (or white) flowers with prominent red/crimson stamens. Petals are edible and taste like marshmallows. Blooms late spring to early summer (May-June). Attracts bees and birds for pollination.
fruitInfo: Egg-shaped, green fruit (edible, sweet, aromatic) matures in autumn.
notes: Evergreen. Silvery foliage. Requires chill hours for fruiting. Deer-resistant. Native to South America.

waterNeeds: Drought-tolerant once established. Requires occasional, deep watering during extended dry periods. Young plants need regular watering.
flowerInfo: Small, pale blue to mauve flowers, appearing in terminal racemes. Blooms from late winter to early summer, and sometimes in summer. Attractive to bees and other pollinators.
notes: Evergreen. Aromatic, silvery-gray foliage. Drought, heat, wind, salt tolerant. Deer-resistant. Native to Western Mediterranean.

size: 30-60 feet tall, 20 feet wide (can be smaller with trimming)
waterNeeds: Drought-tolerant once established. Requires regular watering during the first growing season. Container-grown plants need more frequent watering.
flowerInfo: Small, inconspicuous, pale yellow-green flowers, approximately 1 cm in diameter, borne in pairs. Dioecious (male and female on separate plants). Flowers bloom in spring. Pollinated by bees.
fruitInfo: Single-seeded, dark purple berries (female plants only).
notes: Evergreen. Aromatic leaves (culinary herb). Native to Mediterranean. Deer resistant.

size: 3-30 feet tall, 6-30 feet wide (varies by cultivar)
waterNeeds: Drought-tolerant once established. Young plants require regular, deep watering. Mature plants only need watering during prolonged dry periods.
flowerInfo: Flowers with crimped, wavy petals in panicles up to 9 cm long. Colors include white, pink, mauve, purple, carmine, or red. Blooms from July to September.
notes: Deciduous. Valued for flowers and exfoliating bark. Native to China.

waterNeeds: Moderate water needs. Requires regular watering, especially when young. Mature trees are fairly drought-tolerant.
flowerInfo: Monoecious (male and female cones on same tree). Male cones are 2-3 inches long, shed pollen in autumn. Female cones are erect, purplish, barrel-shaped (2.75-5 inches long), disintegrate at maturity. Cones produced in spring/summer, with some flowering in November. Unremarkable but fragrant.
notes: Evergreen. Pyramidal form. Gracefully drooping branches. Native to Himalayas.

waterNeeds: Requires consistent moisture. Water deeply 1-2 times per week. Drought-tolerant depending on variety.
flowerInfo: Showy, radially symmetrical, hermaphroditic flowers with varied petal counts (5 to many overlapping), colors (white, yellow, orange, pink, red, purple tones), and fragrances. Sizes range from 1.25 cm to over 17.5 cm across. Most bloom from late spring to early fall, peaking in early summer. Primarily grown for their ornamental value.
fruitInfo: Rose hip (glossy, orange to red, edible).
notes: Deciduous. Woody stems often thorny. Highly diverse genus. Native to Northern Hemisphere.

waterNeeds: Requires consistently moist, well-rained soil. Water deeply 1-2 times per week once sprouted. Do not water tubers before they sprout.
flowerInfo: Highly diverse flowers with thousands of cultivars. Colors include red, orange, yellow, pink, and purple (no true blue). Features central disc florets and surrounding ray florets (mistaken for petals). Sizes vary from small to 'dinner plate-sized' (up to 30 cm across). Most are not scented. Bloom continuously from early to midsummer until frost.
notes: Tender perennial (tubers). Vast array of flower types and colors. Native to Mexico/Central America.

size: 40-70 feet tall, 10 feet wide (landscape) to 150 feet (wild)
waterNeeds: Very drought-tolerant once established. Requires deep and infrequent watering. Young trees need consistent moisture.
flowerInfo: Monoecious (separate male and female cones on the same tree). Blooms in May. Female cones are small, ovoid, with a distinctive hook shape. Male cones are pollen-bearing, not showy. Not a true flowering plant; reproduces via cones.
notes: Evergreen. Aromatic needles. Used for pencils. Native to Western North America.

size: 18 inches to 4 feet tall (flower stalks 2-3 feet)
waterNeeds: Weekly watering during summer, less in winter. Drought-tolerant once established. Prefers well-rained soil.
flowerInfo: Broadly funnel-shaped flowers, ranging from pale to deep blue, with a thick texture and a dark blue stripe down the center of each petal. Appear in clusters (implied by "lily of the Nile" description and typical Agapanthus growth). Blooms during summer.
notes: Rhizomatous perennial. Evergreen or deciduous. Low-maintenance. Native to Southern Africa.

waterNeeds: Average water needs. Prefers moist, well-rained soil. Water every 2-3 days during the growing season, and once a week in summer.
flowerInfo: Dense clusters of bright yellow, bell-shaped flowers with six stamens and six petals. Appear in early spring (March to May). Attractive to birds and pollinating insects.
fruitInfo: Clusters of tiny blue, grape-like berries (edible).
notes: Evergreen. Glossy, leathery leaves. Native to North America. State flower of Oregon.

waterNeeds: Prefers moist, well-rained soil. Requires about one inch of water per week. Drought-tolerant once established.
flowerInfo: Hardy, trumpet-shaped blooms that typically open for only a single day. Wide array of colors, including red, orange, and yellow, with nearly every hue represented except for true white and blue. Blooms continuously from early to midsummer until frost.
notes: Herbaceous perennial. Clump-forming. Wide range of cultivars. Native to Eurasia. Safe for humans and humans.

waterNeeds: Drought-tolerant once established. Water once per week, allowing the soil to dry out between waterings. Prefers well-rained soil.
flowerInfo: Fragrant (sweetly scented at night), violet to lilac-pink, star-shaped flowers with tubular bases and six pointed tepals. Borne in large clusters (umbels) on wiry stems. Flowers from midsummer to autumn, or nearly year-round in mild climates. Edible.
notes: Evergreen. Aromatic foliage (garlic scent). Edible leaves and flowers. Deer-resistant. Native to South Africa.

lightRequirements: Full sun to partial shade (tolerates full shade)
waterNeeds: Drought-tolerant once established. Prefers consistent moisture and weekly watering, but can tolerate short dry spells.
flowerInfo: Small, intensely fragrant, sweet-smelling, bell-shaped or funnel-shaped flowers (creamy white to silvery-white or yellowish). Appear in axillary clusters, sometimes hidden by foliage. Blooms primarily in fall (October to November). Attracts bees and pollinators.
fruitInfo: Brown drupes (turn red in spring, fruit not common on this variety).
notes: Evergreen. Striking variegated foliage (yellow center, green margins). Spiny branches. Salt/wind tolerant. Native to Japan.

waterNeeds: Very drought-tolerant. Requires minimal watering. Water only when the soil is dry.
flowerInfo: Inconspicuous, greenish or yellow-green flowers. Surrounded by showy, bright sulphur-yellow bracts (sometimes tinged red) that are often mistaken for flowers. Bracts can fade to dusty pink. Flowers grow in clusters. Blooms mid-spring to early summer.
notes: Succulent perennial. Sprawling/trailing. Evergreen in mild climates. Invasive in some regions. Produces toxic sap.

size: 2-3 feet tall and wide (can be taller)
waterNeeds: Drought-tolerant once established. Prefers regular watering during the growing season, with soil allowed to dry between waterings.
flowerInfo: Dark red, nectar-laden flower spikes (racemes) that are 30–80 cm long, consisting of many dark maroon to rusty reddish flowers. Possess a cup-shaped nectary. Appear in spring. Attractive to birds and bees in its native habitat.
notes: Evergreen. Large, deeply incised, blue-green leaves. Native to South Africa.

size: 2-3 feet tall, 3-4 feet wide (foliage); flower stalks 4-6 feet
waterNeeds: Extremely drought-tolerant. Requires minimal watering once established. Can often survive on rainfall alone.
flowerInfo: Clusters of tubular to bell-shaped flowers, typically red, coral, or salmon-pink, on tall, slender flower stalks (up to 6 feet). Blooms from spring to fall (or even year-round in mild climates). Attracts hummingbirds.
notes: Evergreen succulent. Blue-green leaves. Attracts hummingbirds. Native to Texas, New Mexico, Mexico.

waterNeeds: Drought-tolerant once established. Requires weekly watering during the first growing season.
flowerInfo: Small, yellowish-green, inconspicuous flowers. Appear in May.
fruitInfo: Purplish, half-inch-long capsules (split to reveal orange-coated seeds).
notes: Deciduous. Striking scarlet fall foliage. Invasive in many regions of Eastern US. Toxic.

waterNeeds: Prefers consistently moist, but not waterlogged, soil. Regular watering is required, especially when newly planted. Drought-tolerant once established.
flowerInfo: Fragrant, star-shaped, bluish-white or white flowers with tiny, yellow centers or golden stamens. Bloom abundantly from June to October (or even into early autumn). Attracts butterflies and other pollinators.
notes: Evergreen/semi-evergreen climber. All parts poisonous. Native to Brazil/South America.

size: 2-4 feet tall and wide (can be taller)
waterNeeds: Regular watering is required, especially during the first year. Established plants are more drought-tolerant but still benefit from watering during dry periods. Prefers well-rained soil.
flowerInfo: Small, inconspicuous, or insignificant flowers. Bloom in April.
notes: Evergreen. Dense foliage. Good for hedges/topiaries. Native to Japan. Shallow root system.

waterNeeds: High (requires significant fog or rain)
flowerInfo: Monoecious (pollen and seed cones on same tree)
notes: The Yurok people traditionally used fire to manage redwood forests for medicine and basketry materials. These giants can absorb water directly through their bark and leaves! Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sequoia_sempervirens

waterNeeds: High
flowerInfo: Conifer (produces seed cones)
notes: Highly fire-adapted; their cones open immediately after a forest fire to release seeds into fresh, mineral-rich ash. Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sequoiadendron_giganteum

waterNeeds: Drought-tolerant
flowerInfo: Solitary, 4 silky petals, yellow to orange
notes: Used as traditional medicine and cosmetics by the Tongva and Pomo peoples. It became California's official state flower in 1903. Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eschscholzia_californica

waterNeeds: Moderate
flowerInfo: Purplish-blue, occasionally white or yellow
notes: Indigenous peoples like the Pomo extracted strong, flexible fibers from the leaf margins to create high-quality nets and snares. Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iris_douglasiana

size: Up to 4 feet tall and wide
waterNeeds: Drought-tolerant
flowerInfo: Tubular, 5 broad lobes, usually light orange
notes: Used by Miwok and Pomo tribes to treat sores and burns. It's a critical host plant for the common buckeye butterfly. Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diplacus_aurantiacus

waterNeeds: Moderate to high (prefers moist locations)
flowerInfo: Red and yellow, 5 cm long, edible
notes: Some Plateau Indian tribes used these flowers to create perfume. They are a favorite of hummingbirds! Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aquilegia_formosa

waterNeeds: Drought-tolerant
flowerInfo: Rounded clusters of bright lavender or pink
notes: Traditionally steeped into a bitter mint tea by indigenous Californians to treat stomach upset and sore throats. Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monardella_villosa

size: Up to 5 feet tall, 8 feet wide
waterNeeds: Low
flowerInfo: Small white and pink clusters, turns rusty after bloom
notes: California's most important native source of honey. The Tongva used the roots to treat headaches and stomach pain. Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eriogonum_fasciculatum

waterNeeds: Low
flowerInfo: Small cream-colored flowers on long spadices
notes: Natives used the sweet fruit for food and the fronds for roofing and sandals. The 'skirt' of dead leaves provides habitat for many small animals. Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washingtonia_filifera

waterNeeds: Very low
flowerInfo: Creamy white to green tepals in panicles
notes: Named by Mormon colonists who saw the tree's limbs as the upraised arms of Joshua. It relies entirely on the yucca moth for pollination. Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yucca_brevifolia

waterNeeds: Low (drought-tolerant)
flowerInfo: Small greenish-yellow, no petals
fruitInfo: Acorn-shaped ovoid capsule, dark brown seed
notes: Native Americans used heated jojoba seeds as a salve for skin and hair. The seeds were also eaten to assist during childbirth. Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simmondsia_chinensis

waterNeeds: Low (drought-tolerant)
flowerInfo: Small male cones shedding pollen in spring
notes: The wood was prized for making sinew-backed bows, and the berries were ground into meal for baking. Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Juniperus_californica

waterNeeds: Low to moderate
flowerInfo: Bright yellow, pea-like flowers
fruitInfo: Flat seed pods with hard shells
notes: Used by the Quechan and Mojave for food (beans) and the wood was carved into beautiful ladles. It is the state tree of Arizona. Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parkinsonia_florida

waterNeeds: Low (drought-tolerant)
flowerInfo: Acute-globose female cones, green ripening yellow-buff
fruitInfo: Edible pine nuts in seed cones
notes: The only one-needled pine in the world! Its nuts are dispersed by the pinyon jay, which 'plants' them in hidden caches. Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pinus_monophylla

waterNeeds: High (riparian species)
flowerInfo: Long drooping catkins
notes: The inner bark is rich in Vitamin C and was used to prevent scurvy. Its fluffy seeds look like patches of cotton in the air. Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Populus_fremontii

waterNeeds: Very low
flowerInfo: Bright crimson flowers at stem tips
notes: Stems are often used to make 'living fences' because they root easily. They bloom in bright crimson after desert rains. Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fouquieria_splendens

waterNeeds: Very low (extremely drought-tolerant)
flowerInfo: Five yellow petals, 25 mm diameter
notes: One clonal colony, 'King Clone,' is estimated to be 11,700 years old! Its resin was used as a durable pottery glue. Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Larrea_tridentata

waterNeeds: Low
flowerInfo: Bowl-shaped apricot to orange flowers
notes: Used by the Shoshoni as a food source and medicine. It effectively out-competes invasive grasses like cheatgrass. Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sphaeralcea_ambigua

waterNeeds: Very low
flowerInfo: Yellow ray florets with yellow or purple-brown discs
notes: Spanish friars used the dried sap as incense, similar to frankincense. Desert tribes used it as glue for arrow shafts. Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Encelia_farinosa

size: Rosette up to 2 feet tall, stalk up to 20 feet
waterNeeds: Low
flowerInfo: Numerous yellow funnel-shaped flowers on tall panicle
notes: A desert staple; tribes roasted the hearts and flower stalks for food and used the leaf fibers for cloth and rope. Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agave_deserti

size: Up to 9.8 feet tall, 20 inches wide
waterNeeds: Low
flowerInfo: Funnel-shaped, maroon outside, bright yellow inside
fruitInfo: Fleshy, hollow, spherical, yellow, about 3 cm long
notes: Known as 'miner's compass' because it often leans toward the south to maximize sun and protect its growing tip. Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ferocactus_cylindraceus

size: Stalk up to 5 feet, leaves up to 30 inches
waterNeeds: Low
flowerInfo: White to cream-coloured with purple shades
fruitInfo: Fleshy, banana-shaped, edible (tastes like sweet potato)
notes: The fleshy fruit tastes like sweet potato when roasted! Paiutes dried the fruit for a reliable winter food source. Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yucca_baccata

waterNeeds: Very low
flowerInfo: White, bell-shaped in compact clusters
fruitInfo: Elongate berry up to 11.5 cm long
notes: Extracts are today used in dog food to reduce waste odor! Traditionally, the roots were a primary source of soap. Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yucca_schidigera

waterNeeds: Very low
flowerInfo: Small white flowers in panicles
notes: The Tongva made a strong bark tea to treat skin infections and snakebites. Its wood was used for fire-hardened arrow points. Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adenostoma_fasciculatum

flowerInfo: White flowers with five petals in racemes
fruitInfo: Small purple pome with waxy bloom
notes: The berries have a sweet, nutty taste and were a key ingredient in pemmican. They are a favorite of bears and squirrels! Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amelanchier_alnifolia

flowerInfo: Hanging clusters of narrow urn-shaped white flowers
fruitInfo: Round red drupe containing fused nutlets
notes: Allelopathic, meaning it secretes chemicals to stop other plants from growing nearby. The fruits were often made into cider. Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arctostaphylos_glauca

waterNeeds: Low
flowerInfo: Sparse inflorescences with yellowish or red disk flowers
notes: A keystone species; it provides critical habitat for the endangered California gnatcatcher. Known as 'cowboy cologne.' Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artemisia_californica

waterNeeds: Low
flowerInfo: Creamy white (female) or flatter yellow (male) flowers
notes: A primary pioneer plant that quickly reclaims grasslands. It provides a massive amount of nectar for predatory wasps and flies. Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baccharis_pilularis

flowerInfo: Small clusters of bright blue to purple flowers
notes: Endemic to the bluffs and mountain slopes of the San Francisco Bay Area coastline. Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ceanothus_gloriosus

waterNeeds: Low to moderate
flowerInfo: Lavender to light pink with yellow ridges and purple lines
fruitInfo: Linear pod containing numerous winged seeds
notes: Though it looks like a willow, it's actually a relative of the trumpet vine! Used traditionally to treat fungal infections. Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chilopsis_linearis

size: Up to 20 feet tall, 12 feet wide
waterNeeds: Very low
flowerInfo: Showy yellow flowers, up to 6 cm wide
notes: The wood was used by the Yokuts for making furniture, while the fuzzy hairs on the leaves can be a skin and eye irritant! Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fremontodendron_californicum

waterNeeds: Low
flowerInfo: Small white flowers in racemes
notes: Native Californians fermented the sweet fruit pulp into an intoxicating drink and made meal from the leached seeds. Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prunus_ilicifolia

waterNeeds: Moderate to high (riparian)
flowerInfo: Dark red to burgundy, spicy-scented
notes: The flowers are uniquely pollinated by beetles! It grows along streams and has a wonderful, wine-like spicy scent. Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Calycanthus_occidentalis

flowerInfo: Showy white flowers with yellow centers
notes: An incredibly rare species found at only seven sites in Fresno and Madera Counties. It thrives in gardens but is endangered in the wild. Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carpenteria_californica

flowerInfo: Clusters of yellow flowers
notes: The Kumeyaay consumed the flowers with tortillas or acorn mush. Immature pods can be pickled and eaten like capers! Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peritoma_arborea

flowerInfo: Purple to blue spikes
notes: Critical for the survival of the endangered Mission Blue butterfly. The plant changes flower color after pollination to tell bees to move on! Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lupinus_albifrons

flowerInfo: Small pinkish-white bell-shaped flowers
notes: The white berries have a soapy texture due to saponins and were used traditionally as a natural soap. Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symphoricarpos_mollis

flowerInfo: Pinkish bell-shaped flowers
fruitInfo: Black or dark blue edible berries
notes: The berries were a favorite traditional food. In the early 1900s, it became scarce because its foliage was so popular for flower arrangements! Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vaccinium_ovatum
Its tannin-rich bark once supported a massive American leather industry. Its acorns were a dietary staple for thousands of years. Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Notholithocarpus_densiflorus

flowerInfo: Small white urn-shaped flowers
notes: Nicknamed the 'refrigerator tree' because its bark stays cool in summer. Its beautiful peeling red bark is unmistakable. Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arbutus_menziesii

flowerInfo: Greenish-yellow pendulous racemes
notes: Has the largest leaves of any maple—up to 2 feet across! You can even make maple syrup from its sap. Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Acer_macrophyllum

flowerInfo: Creamy white flat-topped clusters
notes: The wood was traditionally used to make musical flutes and whistles. The flowers and berries make delicious teas and jellies. Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sambucus_cerulea

flowerInfo: Sweet-scented white to pale pink panicles
fruitInfo: Fig-shaped capsule with large poisonous seed
notes: Tribes like the Pomo used the toxic seeds to stupefy fish in streams, making them easy to catch. The flowers are toxic to honeybees! Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aesculus_californica

flowerInfo: Bright pink or magenta pea-like flowers
fruitInfo: Thin brown or reddish-purple legume pods
notes: Indigenous Californians use the twigs for weaving baskets. As a legume, it actually improves soil by adding nitrogen! Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cercis_occidentalis

fruitInfo: Small hard edible nut in thick shell
notes: The nuts were a favorite food of the Chumash and Tongva. It's often used today as a hardy rootstock for commercial walnut orchards. Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Juglans_californica

flowerInfo: Male catkins and small female flowers
fruitInfo: Nut enclosed in a beak-like husk
notes: The hardiest of all hazel species, surviving down to -50°C! Stems were used for baskets and fish traps. Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Corylus_cornuta

fruitInfo: Medium to dark brown acorns, 2-3 cm long
notes: The largest of all North American oaks! Its sweet acorns were a primary dietary staple for many Native American groups. Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quercus_lobata
